column4: i want to run both php4 and php5 on a server.. how can i do this in ubuntu? i see no packages for php4 in the repositories
not really a good idea
apache only really likes one version loaded, it's quite an admin to seperate
there is? cool :)
sorry, that wasn't for you
i know :)
per system
who can install them?
administrator users
hm.. non-administrator users were able to add/remove printers here
how
have no idea
they will be able to connect to existing printers, but they won't be able to add a new printer to the system
through system - administration - printers
ahhh, thats fine, don't worry about that
well.. they were able to remove the printers used by all the other users of the system as well
sorry, thats probably a bad "definition" on my part, that is a user configuring a printer for their use, not adding it to the system
look if the user doing it is in the "admin" group
i think i found the error
the user was in the lpadmin group
perfect
going to retry now
and what i can do about it
best to just ask the question
well.. that's just the question.. because it looks like it's the most evil motherboard out there..
do you have a question about it relevant to ubuntu
yeah.. why it all of a sudden causes segmentation faults all over the place
why do you think that's the motherboard ?
because a google search for A7N8X reveals some previous issues about it
so what's your actual support question
why i'm getting seg faults?
what applications are seg faulting ?
dbus
really, anything else or pretty much dbus
Oct 18 17:30:01 tahiti kernel: [265706.499928] dbus-daemon[2106]: segfault at 1 ip b8e39cd8 sp bf8e90b4 error 6
then after that everything seg faults
can't even do 'ls' or 'dmesg'

ok, two things you need to check, would be 1.) a memory check using the memcheck tool 2.) unplug all external devices (usb disks, bluetooth dongles etc etc) and run it for a while without them, that's my first set of debugging tips
well.. it has to be the memory, then, because i have no external stuff connected to it
may not be memory, but it's just a core thing thats very worth checking
yeah, true that
lets remove the main stuff first
will check it out
every ubuntu installation comes with memtest, right?
during boot-up, i mean?
use visudo to edit the sudoers file and create a ALL= group for just that one command
you told me about as much as i already know :)
so what's the problem then ?
i know the basics, but not how to separate on different commands
so ALL=/etc/init.d/network
hosts and commands
hosts and commands
still makes no sense.. there's three "ALL" in ALL=(ALL) ALL
how can that then mean just hosts and commands?
first all is what hosts you're authorized on, second all is what commands you're allowed on the authorized hosts
and third "ALL"?
there should only be two
that's two
no, the second is a response to ALL =
the second means all commands
well, now i understand even less
all=ls all=((all) - as in the first is ls only, the second is all commands
that means all commands
and ALL doesn't?
the first ALL is "define all" the (ALL) is "all commands
gah :D
totally not getting it
ok, here we go
ok, so the ALL= means "what is the list of all commands the users can run"
follow that ?
so it's like a variable?
or.. rather.. a key..?
yes, so ALL=ls would mean, all the commands you can run is "ls" only
why not just call it COMMANDS=?
I didn't write sudo
(and you can actually do it like that)
but you agree it makes more sense?
not really,
so ALL=(ALL) means you can run all commands
you can make sudo MUCH more complicated with veriables like COMMANDS so ALL=(GROUP@ COMMANDS) etc, that's why "ALL" is used,
pretty much yes
ok, so to summarize.. if i want a specific user to be able to bring down and up the network interfaces, then i need him to have access to ifup and ifdown?
so like: user ALL=/sbin/ifup, /sbin/ifdown ALL?
just ifconfig should do it
and that means he can run /etc/init.d/networking script as well?
no, that's a seperate command
yes, but if you are using 64bit it's a very VERY dirty hack, 32bit is less
tell me about it :)
and i'm of course running 64-bit :)
the honest answer is, even symatic don't support it (I know their website says they do) but they don't support anything beyond 8.04 due to the dirty hacks,
well, give me the dishonest answer then :)
yes, it's fully supported by symantec and works out of the box
hehe
